metadata.case_name: Y. Narayana Chetty & Chilla Pitchayya v. Income-tax Officer, Nellore Circle

facts.text: The firm Ms. Bellapu Audeyya and Chilla Pitchayya was formed on April 20, 1936, and dissolved on March 31, 1948. It consisted of two partners, Chilla Pitchayya and Bellapu Audeyya.
Chilla Pitchayya started another firm G. Pitchayya Co. with partner R. Subba Rao, formed on July 30, 1941, and dissolved on March 31, 1949.
Bellapu Audeyya and Chilla Pitchayya formed Prabhat Textiles with five other partners on December 1, 1941, dissolved by civil court decree on December 22, 1949, effective from January 1, 1949.
All three firms carried on business in yarn and cloth and were registered under s. 26A of the Indian Income-tax Act.
For assessment years 1943-44 and 1944-45, Income-tax Officer, Nellore Circle (respondent 1) treated each firm as separate entity and passed separate assessment orders.
On August 14, 1951, respondent 1 issued notice under s. 34 against Prabhat Textiles.

In s. 34 proceedings for Prabhat Textiles, respondent 1 held the firm fictitious, real partners C. Pitchayya and B. Audeyya, cancelled registration under r. 6B, passed fresh assessments as unregistered firm for 1943-44 on August 14, 1952, and 1944-45 on February 25, 1953.
Similar action taken by respondent 1 against the other two firms on same dates.

Y. Narayana Chetty, partner of Prabhat Textiles, filed Writ Petition No. 613 of 1952 in Madras High Court under Art. 226 for writ of prohibition against proceedings per notice of August 14, 1951, and assessment order of August 14, 1952, for 1943-44.
Chilla Pitchayya filed Writ Petition No. 201 of 1953 for similar relief re Prabhat Textiles 1944-45; Nos. 629 of 1952 and 202 of 1953 re other firms for 1943-44 and 1944-45.
Four writ petitions heard together and dismissed by Madras High Court on March 5, 1954.
High Court granted certificate under Art. 133 read with O. XLV rr. 1,2,3,8 that value exceeded Rs. 20,000.
Y. Narayana Chetty appellant in Civil Appeal No. 317 of 1957; Chilla Pitchayya in Nos. 318,319,320 of 1957.
High Court noted appellants admitted filing appeals against challenged orders.
Notice under s. 34 served on appellant C. Pitchayya on behalf of firms; averred income under-assessed; required return within 35 days; Pitchayya appeared.
ITO finding: only B. Audeyya and C. Pitchayya had interest in businesses; B. Audeyya did not challenge proceedings.
Appellants made applications under s. 27 against fresh assessment orders.

legal_issues.text: Whether proceedings under s. 34 invalid because notice issued to firms instead of individual partners.
Whether cancellation of registration under r. 6B ultra vires.
Whether illegal to assess escaped income under s. 34 as unregistered firm while original assessment treated firms as registered.
Whether High Court should exercise jurisdiction under Art. 226 given alternative remedies.

petitioner_arguments.text: Proceedings under s. 34 invalid as notice not issued to individual partners but to firms; assessee under s. 2(2) is individual partner liable under s. 23(5); firm not assessee.
Notices must be to individual partners post-dissolution; s. 63(2) applies only to existing firms.
r. 6B ultra vires as inconsistent with s. 23(4); only s. 23(4) permits cancellation for defaults, not for fictitious firm.
Revised assessment illogical: original as registered, escaped income as unregistered; whole assessment must be consistent.

respondent_arguments.text: Firm is assessee under s. 3; notice to firm valid; served on Pitchayya; other partners no grievance; B. Audeyya not challenging.
r. 6B valid to cancel registration erroneously granted to non-genuine firm; distinct from penalty under s. 23(4).
Preliminary objections: discretionary refusal of writ; alternative remedy of appeals filed; no jurisdiction for prohibition against tax authorities.

court_reasoning.text: Notice under s. 34(1)(a) to firm valid; firm is assessee under s. 3; 'person' includes firm; assessment process starts with firm under ss. 22,23; partners assessed via share allocation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Firm does not cease to be assessee under s. 23(5); clarified by 1956 amendment.

court_reasoning.text: Post-dissolution, notice to Pitchayya sufficient; no notice of discontinuance u/s 25(2); other partners no grievance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s. 63(2) allows address to any member.

court_reasoning.text: r. 6B intra vires; for non-genuine firms where registration erroneously granted; distinct from s. 23(4) penalty for defaults; carries out s. 26A purpose.
No prejudice as notice and opportunity given despite r. 6B not requiring it.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Validity not challenged on lack of notice here.

court_reasoning.text: Issue of inconsistent registered/unregistered treatment not jurisdictional; raise in appeals u/s 23 or s. 27 applications.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Writ of prohibition under Art. 226 not for merits.

holdings.text: Notice under s. 34(1)(a) validly issued to firm as assessee.
Third contention on inconsistent assessments not decided on merits as not jurisdictional for Art. 226 writ.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Ramsukh Motilal
precedents_cited.relevance: Notice under s. 34 condition precedent to reassessment; invalid notice voids proceedings.

precedents_cited.case_name: B. K. Das Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Notice under s. 34 condition precedent; invalid notice voids proceedings.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ravula Subba Rao v. Commissioner of I.T., Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Rules 2 and 6 under s. 59 not ultra vires (distinguished from r. 6B).

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs reassessment notices to firms, registration, assessment of partners, rule-making.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Cancellation of registration for fictitious firms.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Madras High Court dismissal of writ petitions on merits of main contentions; did not decide preliminary objections or third contention as non-jurisdictional.

key_quotes.text: The notice prescribed by s. 34 cannot be regarded as a mere procedural requirement; it is only if the said notice is served on the assessee as required that the Income-tax Officer would be justified in taking proceedings against him.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes notice as condition precedent to s. 34 validity.

key_quotes.text: A firm is specifically treated as an assessee by s. 3.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Firm is assessee for notice purposes.

key_quotes.text: Rule 6B has been made to confer on the Income-tax Officer in express and specific terms such authority to review his own decision in the matter of the registration of the firm when he discovers that his earlier decision proceeded on a wrong assumption about the existence of the firm.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Upholds r. 6B validity for fictitious firms.
